perturbation.original_text: (v) During the Term and during the sell-off period, MusclePharm shall make royalty payments in U.S. dollars for the respective quarters ending on the last day of September, December, March and June (each, a "Royalty Period") within thirty (30) days from the end of each quarterly period. Each such royalty payment shall include an itemized statement showing the nature and source of such royalties, including (i) the number of units of Licensed Products sold (by country and customer); (ii) the total number of units returned for which credit was given and the total dollar amount of such credits, and (iii) the total gross sales and the total royalties due with respect to such gross sales, and each itemized statement shall be certified by a duly authorized officer of MusclePharm. Such statements shall be in the form attached hereto as Exhibit "B" and furnished to Lender whether or not any Licensed Products were sold during the Royalty Period.
perturbation.changed_text: (v) During the Term and during the sell-off period, MusclePharm shall make royalty payments in U.S. dollars for the respective quarters ending on the last day of September, December, March and June (each, a "Royalty Period") within ninety (90) days from the end of each quarterly period. Each such royalty payment shall include an itemized statement showing the nature and source of such royalties, including (i) the number of units of Licensed Products sold (by country and customer); (ii) the total number of units returned for which credit was given and the total dollar amount of such credits, and (iii) the total gross sales and the total royalties due with respect to such gross sales, and each itemized statement shall be certified by a duly authorized officer of MusclePharm. Such statements shall be in the form attached hereto as Exhibit "B" and furnished to Lender whether or not any Licensed Products were sold during the Royalty Period.
perturbation.explanation: California law requires royalty payments to be made within a reasonable timeframe, typically interpreted as being shorter than 90 days, especially given the nature of the licensed product sales. Extending the payment period to 90 days is an unreasonable delay which could be seen as a breach of good faith and fair dealing under California contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California contract law principles of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Receipt or acceptance by Lender (or its authorized representative) of a royalty statement or receipt or acceptance of any accompanying royalty payment shall not prevent Lender from at any time within three years after the Term of this Agreement questioning the validity or accuracy of such royalty statement or payment.
perturbation.changed_text: Receipt or acceptance by Lender (or its authorized representative) of a royalty statement or receipt or acceptance of any accompanying royalty payment shall act as a full waiver of Lender’s right to question the validity or accuracy of such royalty statement or payment.
perturbation.explanation: Under California law, a waiver of rights must be knowing and voluntary. By stating acceptance acts as a waiver, it may not be knowing and intentional. This is an attempt to restrict Arnold's ability to dispute royalty statements, conflicting with CA law that protects individuals from unknowingly waiving their legal rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code § 1542, California waiver law.

perturbation.changed_text: (b) Endorser shall not use or provide endorsements or testimonials for products that compete with MusclePharm Products or the Licensed Products. Any failure of Endorser to disclose such conflicting interests, or any breach of this Section, shall be deemed a material breach of the Agreement. Endorser's duty not to compete with the business of MusclePharm shall continue perpetually following the expiration or termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 generally prohibits non-compete agreements, unless they fall under specific exceptions (like the sale of a business). Extending the non-compete obligation perpetually is an unreasonable restraint of trade and is likely unenforceable under California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
